content.description: The Sahale Glacier route ascends the Sahale Glacier to the SW side of the summit pyramid base.  Steeper snow or 3rd and 4th class scrambling leads to a flat ledge/mini saddle below a short chimney-like feature on the south side of the pyramid, which is climbed to the summit (5.0).
content.protection: A few pieces of rock pro can protect the final moves to the summit.  There is typically a slung block on top which serves as a rappel station.  Roping up on glaciers is generally a good idea, though the Sahale Glacier is small and not very active.
content.location: From Cascade Pass, hike the Sahale Arm to Sahale Glacier camp.  Glacier travel begins beyond this point.

content.description: From Boston Basin, ascend along the left (North) side of the Quien Sabe glacier until you reach the base of Sharkfin Tower between the summits of Sahale and Boston Peak. Traverse South along the base of the rock face until you reach the col. The glacier is steeper here and be sure to watch for crevasses. Traverse exposed snow to reach the loose class 3 summit scramble. Watch out for a cornice that lasts into early summer.
content.protection: A few Slings for the 4th class summit block, maybe a few pickets for the steeper snow sections.
content.location: From Marblemount, drive east on Cascade River road 21.7 miles to the fork. At 3200 feet, follow the abandoned Diamond Mine road for .75 miles and then follow the trail across 4 stream crossings over the next half mile. There are camping sites at a little over 5000 feet and 6000 feet with compost toilets. To get to the basin it is a 3 hour hike on a unmaintained climbers trail. Boston Basin is a very popular location for climbers because of its beautiful scenery and alpine grandeur.

pathTokens: Hwy 20 and North Cascades National Park
